revisions.rev:
[[File:Vladimir Horowitz LOC 3b00629.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=A half-length portrait of Vladimir Horowitz stood by the steps of a boat, facing left. The photo was taken in 1931, when Vladimir Horowitz was in his late twenties. He is wearing a long coat, leather gloves, a white shirt and a tie.|Vladimir Horowitz in 1931.]]
The [[Russian-American]] classical virtuoso pianist [[Vladimir Horowitz]]<ref name="Allmusic">{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=q7472/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Vladimir Horowitz > Biography|publisher=[[Allmusic]]|accessdate=2010-03-15}}</ref> was a recording artist for over 60 years; beginning in 1926 on a [[piano roll]] system for [[Welte-Mignon]], then with audio recordings, starting in 1928 for [[RCA Records|RCA Victor]].<ref name="Plaskin">{{cite book|title=Horowitz, a biography|last=Plaskin|first=Glenn|year=1983|publisher=Quill books|isbn=0-688-02656-7|page=115}}</ref> Horowitz continued to record for a variety of record labels throughout his life. He stopped recording for RCA in 1959, and between 1962 and 1973 recorded with [[Columbia Masterworks]],<ref name="Columbia Masterworks">{{cite album-notes|title=The Complete Masterworks Recordings, Vol. 1: The Studio Recordings 1962â1963|albumlink=|artist=Vladimir Horowitz|year=1993|first=Thomas|last=Frost|authorlink=Thomas Frost|page=7|publisher=Sony Classical}}</ref> now known as [[Sony Masterworks]]. In 1975, Horowitz returned to RCA,<ref name="Dubal pg. 65">{{cite book|title=Evenings with Horowitz â A Personal Portrait|last=Dubal|first=David|authorlink=David Dubal|year=1991|publisher=Amadeus Press|isbn=1-57467-086-7|page=65}}</ref> with which he recorded a series of live recitals. For the last years of his life, between 1985 and 1989, Horowitz recorded for [[Deutsche Grammophon]].<ref name="DG">{{cite web|url=http://www2.deutschegrammophon.com/artist/biography?ART_ID=HORVL|title=Vladimir Horowitz|publisher=[[Deutsche Grammophon]]|accessdate=2010-03-15}}</ref> Horowitzâs final recording, with [[Sony Classical]], was completed in November 1989, four days before his death.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/06/obituaries/vladimir-horowitz-titan-of-the-piano-dies.html|title=Vladimir Horowitz, Titan of the Piano, Dies|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2010-03-15 | first=Bernard | last=Holland | date=1989-11-06}}</ref> This final recording consisted of repertoire that he had never previously recorded.<ref name="Recordings; Horowitz's Parting Gift: Charming Novelties">{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/22/arts/recordings-horowitz-s-parting-gift-charming-novelties.html|title=Recordings; Horowitz's Parting Gift: Charming Novelties|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2010-03-07 | first=Harold C. | last=Schonberg | date=1990-04-22}}</ref> His discography contains numerous albums and [[compilation album|compilations]] of compositions by a variety of composers. Horowitz has also appeared in several video items, most of these were produced in the later years of his life.<ref name="Allmovie">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmovie.com/artist/vladimir-horowitz-33301/filmography|title=Vladimir Horowitz > Filmography|publisher=[[Allmovie]]|accessdate=2010-03-18}}</ref>
== Overview ==
[[File:HorowitzPianoBain2.jpg|thumb|left|alt=A man seated at a piano with his hands on the keyboard.|Horowitz at the time of his first recordings.]]
Horowitz's first recordings were made in 1926, on [[piano roll]]s at the [[Welte-Mignon]] studios in [[Freiburg im Breisgau]], Germany. He also recorded piano rolls for [[Aeolian Company|Aeolian]]. His first audio recordings were made in the [[United States]] during 1928 for [[RCA Victor Red Seal]],<ref name="Plaskin" /> these recordings were made on [[Gramophone record|78rpm]] disks. Because of the economic impact of the [[Great Depression]], RCA Victor agreed to allow its recording artists' European-produced recordings to be made by [[HMV]], RCA's London-based affiliate. Horowitz's first European recording, in 1930, was of [[Sergei Rachmaninoff|Rachmaninoff]]'s [[Piano Concerto No. 3 (Rachmaninoff)|Piano Concerto No. 3]] with [[Albert Coates (musician)|Albert Coates]] and the [[London Symphony Orchestra]], the world premiere recording of that piece. Through 1936, Horowitz continued to make recordings for HMV of solo piano repertoire, including his famous 1932 account of [[Franz Liszt|Liszt]]'s [[Piano Sonata (Liszt)|Sonata in B minor]].<ref name="DG" /> Beginning in 1940, Horowitz's recording activity was again concentrated in the U.S. That year, he recorded [[Johannes Brahms|Brahms]]' [[Piano Concerto No. 2 (Brahms)|Piano Concerto No. 2]], and in 1941, [[Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky|Tchaikovsky]]'s [[Piano Concerto No. 1 (Tchaikovsky)|Piano Concerto No. 1]], both with the [[NBC Symphony Orchestra]] under [[Arturo Toscanini]]. With the creation of the [[LP album|LP]] in the late 1940s, many of his older recordings were reissued in the new format and some items received multiple issues. During Horowitz's second retirement, which began in 1953, he made a series of recordings in his [[New York City|New York]] [[townhouse]], including LPs of [[Alexander Scriabin|Scriabin]] and [[Muzio Clementi|Clementi]]. Horowitz's first [[Stereophonic sound|stereo]] recording, made in 1959, was devoted to two of [[Ludwig van Beethoven|Beethoven]]'s piano sonatas.
In 1962, Horowitz embarked on a series of highly acclaimed recordings for [[Columbia Masterworks]],<ref name="Columbia Masterworks" /> which was later renamed to [[Sony Classical Records|Sony Classical]] after the label was purchased by [[Sony]] in 1990. The most famous among them are his 1965 return concert at [[Carnegie Hall]] and a 1968 recording from his television special, ''Vladimir Horowitz: A Concert at Carnegie Hall'', televised by [[CBS]].<ref name="Dubal">{{cite book|title=Evenings with Horowitz â A Personal Portrait|last=Dubal|first=David|authorlink=David Dubal|year=1991|publisher=Amadeus Press|isbn=1-57467-086-7}}</ref> Horowitz also continued to make studio recordings, including a 1969 recording of ''[[Kreisleriana]]'' by [[Robert Schumann]], which was awarded the Prix Mondial du Disque. All of Horowitz's Columbia recordings were released as a 13-CD set by [[Sony Masterworks]] in 1993.<ref name="Complete Masterworks" /> In 1975, Horowitz returned to RCA Victor,<ref name="Dubal pg. 65" /> now called RCA Red Seal. He made a series of live recordings until 1982. During this period, Columbia also repackaged their Horowitz recordings with reissues including the named Beethoven Sonatas and multiple-LP sets of [[FrÃ©dÃ©ric Chopin|Chopin]]. In 1985, Horowitz signed with [[Deutsche Grammophon]], and made both studio and live recordings until 1989, including his only recording of [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Mozart]]'s [[Piano Concerto No. 23 (Mozart)|Piano Concerto No. 23]].<ref name="DG" /> Four filmed documents were made during this time,<ref name="Allmovie" /> including the telecast of his April 20, 1986 Moscow recital. His final recording, for Sony Classical, was completed four days before his death and consisted of repertoire he had never previously recorded.<ref name="Recordings; Horowitz's Parting Gift: Charming Novelties" />
[[File:Reagans present Vladimir Horowitz with PMOF cropped.jpg|thumb|alt=An elderly man is awarded a medal by a woman, she is attaching it around his neck whilst he grins excitedly.|Horowitz in 1986, receiving the [[Presidential Medal of Freedom]].]]
With the advent of the [[Compact Disc]], the various labels for which Horowitz recorded began reissuing his pre-digital recordings. This began in the mid-1980s and increased in the years immediately following Horowitzâs death. Beginning in 1987, Columbia issued single-composer compilations drawn from various albums. RCA issued many of Horowitzâs recordings on their [[RCA Red Seal Records#Gold Seal|Gold Seal]] mid-priced label. By 1993, both Columbia's and RCA's entire cache of previously issued recordings was available on CD, including several older items which had never appeared on LP. A number of items were issued more than once, including the 1978 recording of [[Sergei Rachmaninoff|Rachmaninoff]]'s [[Piano Concerto No. 3 (Rachmaninoff)|Piano Concerto No. 3]] which was issued on CD in 1987, again in 1993, with a new cover, and in a new [[Audio mastering|remastering]] in 2000. Over the past two decades, several previously unavailable Horowitz recordings have been issued. These include studio and live recordings from the Columbia era, and a collection from Carnegie Hall recitals between 1945 and 1951 which were recorded privately by Horowitz.<ref name="Sony Masterworks to Release Unprecedented Series of Horowitz Recordings">{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/sony-masterworks-to-release-unprecedented-series-of-horowitz-recordings-documenting-legendary-pianists-greatest-years-as-an-interpretive-artist-78539857.html|title=Sony Masterworks to Release Unprecedented Series of Horowitz Recordings...|publisher=[[PR Newswire]]|accessdate=2010-03-18}}</ref> In addition, several smaller labels have issued CDs made from pirate recordings from the 1960s onward and several of Horowitzâs stereo recordings have been issued in the [[Blu-spec CD|blu-spec]] and SHM-CD (Super High Material) formats.
The listing below only contains Compact Disc releases and does not contain 78rpm, LP, [[Compact Cassette|Cassette]], or [[8-track tape]] releases. The videography includes items which have been released on [[VHS]], [[Laserdisc]] and [[DVD]].

== Video releases ==
Horowitzâs first appearance on television was a one-hour recital for the CBS television network in 1968.<ref name="Dubal" /> It has never been issued in its entirety, although clips of the recital have been shown on various documentaries. The pianist also performed at the [[White House]] in 1978, celebrating the 50th Anniversary of his American debut with an all-Chopin recital from the [[East Room (White House)|East Room]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jimmycarterlibrary.org/documents/diary/1978/d022678t.pdf|title=The Daily Diary of President Jimmy Carter â February 26, 1978|publisher=[[Jimmy Carter Library and Museum|Jimmy Carter Library]]|accessdate=2010-03-14}}</ref> Although never officially released on home video, copies of the recital are available from the [[Jimmy Carter Library and Museum|Jimmy Carter Library]]. Horowitzâs debut in Japan, in 1983, was broadcast on Japanese public television.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/28/arts/horowitz-bound-for-japan.html|title=Horowitz Bound for Japan|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2010-03-15 | date=1983-05-28}}</ref> The pianist was under the influence of [[Antidepressant|anti-depressant]] medication, which severely impaired his playing and led to a withdrawal from performance until 1985. Although clips of the recital have appeared on the internet, no material from this time period has been seen on any documentaries. In addition, Horowitz can be seen on various news shows including a 1977 [[60 Minutes]] story.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/video/watch/?id=4683612n|title=12/26/77: Vladimir Horowitz â 60 Minutes|publisher=[[CBS News]]|accessdate=2010-03-14}}</ref>
